title: Example analysis
text:
Here, I will display a brief data analysis of schooling policies during the fall of 2020 (in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic). The data I am using is from MCH Strategic Data (“Covid-19 Impact: School District Operational Status” 2021) and was pulled on November 7, 2022 but represents data from fall 2020. In this analysis, we will be asking the questions: which states had the highest percentage of districts that were fully virtual during the fall of 2020? What about hybrid and fully onsite? We will also investigate the student masking policies for different states, and we will explore the previous questions at the US region level.
The intended audience of this data analysis is school policy makers and local governance boards who are interested in how their state compared to other states across the country during the COVID-19 pandemic.
The MCH data on school district operational statuses reports the delivery mode of a school district in the fall of 2020. Data were collected by reaching out to individual districts, and updates to the dataset were not at regular time increments; we therefore use the finalized version of the fall 2020 dataset. For each district, we have information about whether they are public, private, or catholic, their state, enrollment numbers, and their policies. These policies include the delivery mode characterization (online only, hybrid, on premises, pending, unknown, or other), along with information about specific requirements such as student masking and staff masking.

title: Example analysis
text:
Plots for All Districts

mch %>%
  ggplot(aes(x=Mode, fill=Mode)) +
  geom_bar() +
  theme(legend.position = "")





mch %>%
  ggplot(aes(x=Mode, y=log(Enrollment))) +
  geom_boxplot()





mch_states <- mch %>%
  group_by(State, Region) %>%
  summarise(n_dist = n(),
            Hybrid = sum(Mode=="Hybrid")/n_dist,
            Onsite = sum(Mode=="On Premises")/n_dist,
            Online = sum(Mode=="Online Only")/n_dist,
            StudentMask = sum(StudentMaskPolicy == "Required for all students"),
            StaffMask = sum(StaffMaskPolicy == "Required for all staff"),
            avg_enroll = mean(Enrollment, na.rm=T))


ordered_states <- mch_states %>%
  arrange(Online)

# mch_states %>%
#   ggplot(aes(x=factor(State, levels=ordered_states$State), y=Online, group=1)) +
#   geom_point() +
#   geom_line()

mch_states %>%
  pivot_longer(Hybrid:Online, names_to = "Mode", values_to = "Percent") %>%
  mutate(Mode = factor(Mode, levels=c("Onsite","Hybrid","Online"))) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x=factor(State, levels=ordered_states$State), y=Percent, group=Mode, fill=Mode)) +
  geom_bar(stat="identity") +
  xlab("State")

title: Example analysis
text:
Teaching Mode by State
Now we can break down the delivery modes by state to see how the states differ in terms of the number and percentage of districts with each delivery mode per state.

mch_states <- mch %>%
  group_by(State, Region) %>%
  summarise(n_dist = n(),
            Hybrid = sum(Mode=="Hybrid")/n_dist,
            Onsite = sum(Mode=="Onsite")/n_dist,
            Online = sum(Mode=="Online")/n_dist,
            StudentMask = sum(StudentMaskPolicy == "Required for all students"),
            StaffMask = sum(StaffMaskPolicy == "Required for all staff"),
            avg_enroll = mean(Enrollment, na.rm=T))


ordered_states <- mch_states %>%
  arrange(Online)

# mch_states %>%
#   ggplot(aes(x=factor(State, levels=ordered_states$State), y=Online, group=1)) +
#   geom_point() +
#   geom_line()

mch_states %>%
  pivot_longer(Hybrid:Online, names_to = "Mode", values_to = "Percent") %>%
  mutate(Mode = factor(Mode, levels=c("Onsite","Hybrid","Online"))) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x=factor(State, levels=ordered_states$State), y=Percent, group=Mode, fill=Mode)) +
  geom_bar(stat="identity") +
  xlab("State") +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle =90)) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent) +
  labs(title = "Percentage of Districts with Each Teaching Mode",
       subtitle = "Fall 2020",
       caption = "Including public school districts across U.S.")




We see that Nebraska, Iowa, Kansas, and Nevada have the lowest percentage of strictly virtual schooling, while Maryland, D.C., Delaware, and California have the highest percentage. This leads us to think that there might be some grouping by region of the country happening as well.

title: Example analysis
text:
Summary
In this brief descriptive analysis, we explored the percentages of districts with different delivery modes across states and regions of the United States in fall of 2020. We saw that the majority of districts operated in a hybrid mode. We saw that the average enrollment for districts that operated fully onsite was the smallest (1,689), followed by hybrid (3,101) and then by online districts (5,679). We then investigated mitigation measures and found that for onsite districts, a higher percentage required staff masking than student masking, and there were regional differences in the percentages requiring each group to wear masks. Specifically, the northeast had the highest percentage of onsite districts requiring masks for all students (90.4%) and all staff (91.5%). The lowest percentage of districts requiring all students to wear masks was the southwest (49.2%), and the lowest percentage of districts requiring all staff to wear masks was the southeast (69.7%). For more analysis of this data and similar data on school policy, I wrote a paper comparing several sources measuring school delivery mode during the pandemic (Lupton-Smith et al. 2021).

title: Example analysis
text:
Descriptive Analysis
To begin the analysis, we can first import the data and filter to just include three district categorizations of interest: on premises, hybrid, or online only.

library(readr)
library(tidyverse)
mch <- read_csv("MCH_Fall2020.csv") %>%
  select(-DistrictID)
regions <- read_csv("Regions of US.csv") %>%
  select(-State) %>%
  rename(State = State.Postal.Code)

mch <- mch %>%
  filter(TeachingMethod %in% c("Hybrid","On Premises","Online Only"),
         Control == "Public",
         is.na(DistrictNCES) == F) %>%
  mutate(TeachingMethod = ifelse(TeachingMethod == "On Premises", "Onsite",
                ifelse(TeachingMethod == "Online Only","Online","Hybrid")),
         across(TeachingMethod:ParentOptOutClassroomTeaching, factor)) %>%
  select(-SchoolYear) %>%
  rename(Mode = TeachingMethod,
         State = PhysicalState) %>%
  mutate(Mode = factor(Mode, levels=c("Onsite","Hybrid","Online"))) %>%
  left_join(regions, by="State")

table(mch$Mode) %>% knitr::kable(col.names = c("Delivery Mode", "Number of Districts"))

title: Example analysis
text:
Mitigation Measures
There has been a lot of research since the beginning of the pandemic that has investigated the potential effects of school delivery mode on outcomes, not only in terms of COVID-19 spread, but also in terms of potential learning loss due to the virtual environment. (Lessler et al. 2021) investigated the relationship between school delivery mode and risk of COVID-19 at the household level. They then go a step further to analyze the relationship between specific mitigation measures and the odds of catching COVID-19 or a similar illness. One figure from their paper is included here.






Important



(Lessler et al. 2021) demonstrate in the following figure that certain mitigation measures are associated with a decreased risk of getting Covid like illness, loss of taste/smell, or a positive COVID-19 test result. The dashed line displays the reduction in odds based on a “generic” measure. We can see that student and teacher masking both are associated with a reduction in risk for students attending school onsite.



Odds ratio of COVID-related outcome by mitigation measure




Based on the above results, we investigate the percentage of districts with a delivery mode of fully onsite that include a mask policy for all students, and a mask policy for all staff.

op_policy <- mch %>%
  filter(Mode == "Onsite") %>%
  group_by(State, Region) %>%
  summarise(StudentMask = sum(StudentMaskPolicy == "Required for all students")/n(),
            StaffMask = sum(StaffMaskPolicy == "Required for all staff")/n()) %>%
  arrange(StudentMask)

op_policy %>%
  ggplot(aes(x=factor(State, levels=op_policy$State), y=StudentMask)) +
  geom_point() +
  facet_wrap(~Region, scales="free_x") +
  xlab("State") + ylab("Percent with Student Mask Required") +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle =90)) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent) +
  labs(title = "Percentage of Districts that Require All Students to Mask",
          subtitle = "Fall 2020",
       caption= "Including public districts who taught fully onsite")





mch %>%
  filter(Mode == "Onsite") %>%
  group_by(Region) %>%
  summarise(StudentMask = sum(StudentMaskPolicy == "Required for all students")/n(),
            StudentMask = round(100*mean(StudentMask),1)) %>%
  arrange(desc(StudentMask)) %>%
  kableExtra::kbl(col.names = c("Region", "Percentage of Districts with Student Masking Required"),
               caption = "Percentage of Onsite Districts in each US Region that Require Masking for All Students")
